Kirillov’s belief in unbelief is anticipated by Prince Myshkin in Dostoevsky’s earlier novel, The Idiot. The Russian people, according to Myshkin (part 4, chapter 7), “don’t simply become atheists, but they absolutely believe [uveruiut] in atheism, as in a new faith” (the Russian is cited fom Idiot, 389; my own translation). 41. note: “You shall love [ve’ahavtah] HASHEM your God with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your resources/strength”).
title: In contrast to Christianity, there is no credo (meaning “I believe”) in the Jewish liturgy. The closest approximation in the Jewish liturgy to the Christian credo is the Shema Israel (“Listen, O Israel, HASHEM is our God, HASHEM is [or will be] [the only] one”). Even here, however, immediately following the recitation of the Shema, the worshipper is commanded not necessarily to believe in God, but rather to love him
